description: The Capacity Bidding Program (CBP) is a CPUC-authorized demand response program operated by San Diego Gas & Electric (SDGE) that compensates commercial, industrial, and agricultural customers for committing to reduce electricity consumption during grid emergencies or high-demand periods. The program provides monthly capacity payments for enrollment commitment plus energy payments for actual curtailment performance during events. Participants can enroll directly with SDGE or through third-party aggregators. The program operates May through October with events called weekdays from 11 AM to 7 PM, with day-ahead or day-of notification options and multiple product duration choices.

service_territories: San Diego Gas & Electric service territory - San Diego and southern Orange Counties
geography.notes: Program operates within SDGE service territory in southern California, coordinated with CAISO wholesale market operations

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Available to non-residential bundled customers including those billed on commercial, industrial, or agricultural rate schedules. Also available to Direct Access (DA) and Community Choice Aggregation (CCA) customers.

eligibility.notes: Customers can enroll directly with SDGE or work with third-party demand response aggregators. Most businesses work with aggregators to determine reduction capacity and manage participation. Aggregators determine financial rewards for participants.

notification.notification_notes: Two notification options: (1) Day-Ahead option with notification by 5:00 PM PT the day before an event, or (2) Day-Of option with same-day notification. Day-Of products typically receive higher capacity payment rates. Events called no later than 5:00 PM PT day-ahead for day-ahead products.

products.notes: Historical rate from CPUC authorization. Current 2024-2025 rates not publicly available.

seasonal_rates.notes: May has lowest capacity payment rates of the season. Rates increase through summer months with peak in August.

Capacity payment rates vary by month with highest rates in peak summer months (July-September). Specific 2024-2025 monthly rates not publicly available. August historically has highest rates. Rates decrease in September and October as season ends.

capacity_rate.notes: Capacity payments are paid monthly based on enrolled/nominated capacity. CPUC-approved rates listed in Schedule CBP tariff. Historical baseline rates from CPUC Resolution E-4020 range from $5.37-$6.79 per kW-month for May depending on product. Current 2024-2025 rates approved through 2027 but specific dollar amounts not publicly disclosed. Day-Of products receive higher capacity payments than Day-Ahead products. Longer duration commitment products (4-8 hour) receive slightly higher rates than shorter duration (1-4 hour).

performance_rate.formula: Based on city gate natural gas price with trigger heat rate of 15,000 BTU/kWh
performance_rate.notes: Energy payments are event-based, calculated using natural gas prices with 15,000 BTU/kWh heat rate trigger. Participants can earn energy payments for up to 150% of nominated demand reduction capacity. If no CBP events are called during the month, monthly energy payment is zero. Specific $/kWh rates vary based on prevailing natural gas prices at time of event.

penalty_tiers.description: Proportional payment based on actual performance
Financial penalties apply for failure to perform

penalty_structure.penalty_description: Tiered performance structure with penalties for delivering less than 50% of nominated capacity reduction. Performance between 75-89.99% receives 50% payment. Performance between 50-74.99% receives no payment but no penalty. Performance below 50% incurs financial penalties with larger penalties for larger shortfalls.

bonus_payments.description: Over-performance bonus for exceeding nominated capacity
bonus_payments.conditions: Energy payments available for up to 150% of nominated demand reduction capacity

payment_structure.payment_notes: Program provides two-part compensation: (1) Monthly capacity payments for enrollment commitment regardless of events called, and (2) Event-based energy payments when curtailment occurs. Capacity payment is what SDGE pays aggregators monthly for commitment. Energy payment is what SDGE pays for actual event curtailment. Current incentive rates authorized by CPUC through 2027. Aggregators manage payment distribution to end customers and may structure custom incentive arrangements.

seasons.notes: Program operates May 1 through October 31. Maximum 24 hours of events per month. No annual maximum specified but monthly limit applies.

call_windows.notes: Events called between 11:00 AM and 7:00 PM Pacific Time on weekdays (Monday-Friday), excluding holidays. Weekends (Saturday-Sunday) excluded from event calls.

event_parameters.notes: Participants select from three product duration options (1-4 hr, 2-6 hr, or 4-8 hr) at enrollment. Maximum 24 hours of events per month. SDGE offers both Day-Ahead and Day-Of call options as unique feature compared to other California IOUs. Typical event dispatch is 2-4 hours within the 11 AM - 7 PM window.

event_triggers.trigger_description: Events are called during periods of exceptionally high electricity demand, low supply conditions, or declared grid emergencies. Primary triggers include extreme weather conditions (heat waves), supply shortages, transmission constraints, or system reliability issues. CAISO coordinates with utilities for demand response deployment during emergency conditions or economic dispatch during high price periods.
event_triggers.examples: California heat waves in summer 2024, CAISO Flex Alert declarations, rotating outage warnings, extreme heat events exceeding 100°F in San Diego region

enrollment_period.notes: Enrollment appears to be ongoing throughout the year. Contact SDGE or aggregators for current enrollment windows.

nomination_bidding.notes: Participants must nominate committed demand reduction capacity at enrollment. Capacity nomination determines monthly capacity payment amount. Participants select product duration option (1-4 hr, 2-6 hr, or 4-8 hr) and notification preference (Day-Ahead or Day-Of) at enrollment. Direct enrollment with SDGE requires eligibility confirmation, document submission, and portal access setup.

program_evolution.change_description: CPUC Resolution E-4020 authorized PG&E, SCE, and SDGE to implement Capacity Bidding Program (CBP) to replace California Power Authority Demand Reserves Partnership

Current program rates and structure approved by CPUC through 2027. SDGE offers both Day-Ahead and Day-Of products. Energy Division recommended modifications to capacity payment schedule structure with tiered performance-based payments.

program_history.notes: Program authorized through 2027 by CPUC. Legacy Capacity Bidding Program costs for PG&E in 2024-27 represented 9% of overall CBP budget. SDGE-specific budget allocation not publicly available.

research_notes: Comprehensive research conducted on SDGE Capacity Bidding Program on 2025-10-11. Found substantial program structure information from CPUC Resolution E-4020 including historical baseline capacity payment rates, event parameters, call windows, product duration options, and performance payment tiers. SDGE CBP webpage confirmed program seasons (May-October), eligibility (commercial/industrial/agricultural), call windows (11 AM - 7 PM weekdays), and approved aggregators (Voltus, Enel X). Key limitation: Schedule CBP tariff PDF containing current 2024-2025 capacity payment rates could not be accessed. Historical rates from E-4020 show May capacity payments ranging $5.37-$6.79/kW-month depending on product (Day-Ahead vs Day-Of, duration 1-4 hr vs 4-8 hr), with higher rates in peak summer months. Program has unique Day-Of notification option not offered by other California IOUs. Energy payments are natural gas price-based with 15,000 BTU/kWh heat rate trigger. Performance structure includes tiered penalties: 100% performance = full payment, 90-99% = proportional, 75-89% = 50% payment, 50-74% = no payment/no penalty, <50% = financial penalties. Maximum 24 event hours per month. Program authorized through 2027 by CPUC. For current 2024-2025 rates and detailed operational requirements, direct contact with SDGE (1-866-377-4735, demandresponse@sdge.com) or aggregators (Voltus, Enel X) required.

integration_metadata.battery_optimization_notes: Good candidate program for battery energy storage systems (BESS) in SDGE territory. Key advantages: (1) Predictable call windows (11 AM - 7 PM weekdays) align with typical battery arbitrage opportunities during peak hours, (2) May-October season avoids winter months when battery performance may be impacted, (3) Multiple duration products allow optimization based on battery capacity and discharge capabilities, (4) Day-Of notification option provides flexibility for same-day arbitrage decisions, (5) Over-performance incentives up to 150% of nomination reward larger battery systems, (6) Monthly capacity payments provide guaranteed revenue stream independent of event calls, (7) 24-hour monthly event limit is modest allowing revenue stacking with other programs/arbitrage, (8) Performance below 75% still receives partial/no payment without penalty allowing conservative nominations. Key considerations: (1) Need to model impact of CBP commitments on daily arbitrage revenue during May-October, (2) Day-Ahead vs Day-Of product selection impacts capacity payment rate and operational flexibility, (3) Duration product selection (1-4 hr vs 4-8 hr) must align with battery discharge capability and round-trip efficiency, (4) Baseline calculation methodology critical for accurate performance measurement, (5) Integration with CAISO wholesale markets and other DR programs requires careful coordination. Recommended approach: Enroll through aggregator (Voltus or Enel X) for turnkey management, select Day-Of 2-6 hour product for flexibility, nominate conservative capacity (50-70% of battery capacity) to ensure performance, stack with other revenue sources during non-event periods.
integration_metadata.notes: SDGE CBP is well-structured program with clear performance tiers, multiple product options, and two-part payment structure (capacity + energy). Program design balances utility need for reliable demand response with participant flexibility through duration and notification options. Historical baseline rates from CPUC resolution provide useful benchmarks but current rates likely differ. The Day-Of option unique to SDGE provides valuable flexibility not available in PG&E or SCE CBP programs. Maximum 24 hours per month is relatively low compared to other DR programs, suggesting SDGE uses CBP for reliability events rather than economic dispatch. Natural gas-based energy payment methodology links compensation to wholesale market conditions. Overall good program for battery optimization given predictable parameters, over-performance incentives, and revenue stacking potential.
